div.head: THE PERSIAN QUESTION.
div.p: Dealing with the great local interests which England and Russia alike possess in the Persian Gulf and the difficulties with which the Persian problem besets the paths of these two Powers, the "Tribune" says :-"Russia 'has pushed her trade in the north with great zeal and at heavy sacrifices to her own overtaxed peasantry by bounties, subsidies, and banks ; trained on a Cossack model the only. reliable troops which the Shah possesses, and built (as a private enterprise at least one excellent carriage road. Her loans to the Shah (raised in Paris at 4 per cent., to be lent again in Teheran at 6) reach a total of from four to five millions, and last, but not least, the Customs are virtually in her hands, thanks to the Belgian officials, who everywhere in the East act, with little concealment, as her agents. Trade, too, has gone to her, and has left us, ever since she concluded, by & clever device, the secret tariff treaty, which, under a specious disguise, favoured Russian bat penalised English imports and exports. Up to the Japanese war she certainly had most of the cards in her hands. We could point only to our great work in policing the Persian Gulf, to our still large but menaced trade, and to the vital interests, political and military, which we have in the South-East, as a neighbouring Power. But of late there have been signs of a change. There has been an uprising of the miserable population, led by a patriotic section of the Mullahs, against the Ministers who had 'sold the country to the infidel,' and the leaders, who demanded - and obtained -a Constitution, took refuge at the British Residency, as though they saw in us their natural protectors.

"One can foresee the probable course of events—it has already been rehearsed with a difference in Egypt. There is to day a Shah who borrows, like the Khedive Ismail, to the ruin of his people, and in so doing puts himself at the mercy of the foreigner. His people may revolt (as they are doing already) and turn not only against him, but against one or both of the foreigners. Bankruptcy is always held to be a pretext for intervention ; revolt is always an accepted excuse for occupation. Sooner or later such an arrangement would end in the destruction of the last fiction of Persian independence, and in the ruin of Persia as a nation, precisely at a moment when some sections, at least, of her degraded and down-trodden society seem to be passing through a phase of liberalism which recalls the hopeful aspects of Arabi's Nationalism. To the entanglements and responsibilities in which such an adventure would involve us there might not soon be an end. Other Powers would ask for compensations, and we who set out with the idea of securing a peace which might pave the way for a reduction of our Indian Army, might find that, instead of being quit of our military problems, we had actually carried our advanced lines right co the Russian positions. Much would turn in such an arrangement on the temper of the other party.

A Liberal England and a Liberal Russia might contrive (without any delimitation or partition) to manage a joint control which would be helpful and unaggressive. But & Russia in transition is still the old Russia which has always had not only one, but several governments... It is most unfortunate that the Novoe Vremya' should have formed the idea that we are suing for an understanding. Russia is doomed for so many years to military impotence that we need bo in no hurry to secure her neutrality in the Middle East. On the other hand, she ought to know that we have no thought of taking advantage of her weakness, that we should deplore her accession to a Holy Alliance with the other Conservative Powers, and that we, in common with our friends in France, look forward to the end of her internal crisis and the establishment of constitutional government As an event which will render possible not merely a businesslike arran, ement, but a warm and popular comradeship based on a common faith in democracy and peace.``

div.head: Quarantine.
div.p: It has been decided to apply the plague regulations against arrivals from Bhavnagar in Egyptian ports.

div.head: Helouan Telegraph Offloo.
div.p: From to-day and throughout the reason the Helonan telegraph office will remain open pinterruptedly from 8 am, to 9 p.m. daily.

div.head: Arrival.
div.p: Mr. Edward Kark, tailor, late of Marshall's of St. James' Street, has just returned from London with the latest materials obtainable.

div.head: Abou-Tig.
div.p: Hassan Pasha Wassif, Mondir of Assiont, bae petitioned the Ministry of the Interior to authorize the creation of a local council for AboQ-Tig.

div.head: St. Andrew's Dinner.
div.p: A dinner will be given at the Turf Club, Cairr, on St. Andrew's Day. This, we believe, will be the first St. Andrew's dinner to be given in Cairo.

div.head: Railway Fatality.
div.p: On Thursday evening two natives, a man and & woman, were ran over and killed by an express train at Kous station. The woman's body was horribly mutilated.

div.head: The Cairo Police.
div.p: Hussein Bey Shaker, commandant of the Gharbieh police, has been transferred to Cairo as inspector; he has been provisionally replaced by Helmi Effendi Berzi.

div.head: Public Security.
div.p: There is no truth whatever in the recurrent ramour that the Native General Parquet is to be transferred from the control of the Ministry of Justice to that of the Interior.

div.head: Resignations.
div.p: Dr. Mohamed Bey Shoukri, profesor of the Kasr el ini Medical School, and Hussein Bez Riad, of the Mixed Tribunal, have sent in their resignations, and will be allowed to retire on pension.

div.head: King Victor Emmanuel's Birthday.
div.p: Tomorrow being the 37th anniversary of the King of Italy's birthday, Baron Acton, Italian Consul-General at Alexandria, will hold a reception at the Consulate from 11 8.m. to midday.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: A matinée will be given at the Alhambra Theatre to-morrow afternoon by the Novelli Italian comedy troupe, by whom " Conte di Monte Cristo" will be staged. For the evening performance "Il Fornaretto di Venezia" is billed.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's plagae bulletin records & 080 at Alexandria (the victim being a young native girl living in the Goomrook quarter), and fresh case and death at Port Said.
To-dsy's bulletin reports one admission and one death at Tantal hospital.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: The total imports of coal into Alexandria for this year op to November 8 are 1,111,144. tons, made op as follows: Welch, 597,481 tons, Newcastle 196,826 tons, Scotch 99,029 tone, Yorkshire 165,329 topp, other qualities 52,479 tong. The total for the same period last year was 938,772 tons.

div.head: Post Office Savings Banks.
div.p: Daring last month 1,195 persons deposited L.E. 38 321 in the Post Office Savings Bank, while the amount drawn ont was L.E. 31,981. The total number of depositors from January 1 to October 31 was 56,408 with a total som deposited of LE. 32,410, the net excess in the banks on the 1st November amounting to L.. 300,429.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 8th November, 8 vessels, 4 northward and 4 southward boond, transited the Canal, and paid transit and passenger tell Fr. 214,710.02. Of these vessels, 5 were Bri. tieb, 1 Germen, 1 French, and 1 Austrian. The total revenue since November 1 is Fr. 2,061194 85. During this period, 79 vessels transited the Canal, 43 northward and 36 southward boond.

div.head: A New Nursing Home.
div.p: A nursing home has been opened at the recently constructed Villa Anna. This building is admirably adapted to the acceptance of invalids by its position, the disposition of its rooms, and its installation with up-to-date sanitary appliances. It stands in a fine garden at the tar end of Moharram Bey, exposed on the ore side to the Amir el Bahr and on the other to the Champs Elyséer. Its rooms are large and airy and the furnishing of the house both effective and artistic, while the proprietors have remembered the golden role of avoiding as many dast traps as possible. Patients received at this senatoriom may be attended by their own doctors, who can use the home for performing operations on their patients. Out patients will be received free for consultation with physician, Bargeon, or oculist, and & speciality of the home will be massage treatment. The rooms are plentifully lighted with electricity, and wo most pot neglect to mention the operating theatre, which is fitted with all nece-gary appliances. Patients are attended to by nursing sister.

div.head: GOLD FOR EGYPT.. THE BANK OF FRANCE RELAXES.
div.p: London, November 9. The mes' money article states that the Bank of France is now prepared to allow the withdrawal of * substantial amount of gold for Egypt. (Feuter)
The last monthly journal of the British Chamber of Commerce in Egypt contains the following interesting article upon the financial stringency which Egypt has experienced --
ln view of the recent allusions in the European Press to the extraordinary demand for gold for Egypt, we think a few remarks on the matter may not be out of place.

For the benefit of our hore members we may explain that, although the Arab demands and obtains long credits when he is & bayer, the reverse is the case when the native is a seller. In other words, speaking generally, the whole of the cotton cale trang. actions between the fellaheen and merchants are on a strictly cash basis, payments being made in actual gold, not cheques nor bank notes in soy considerable proportion. Judging by the past few years, the native, ag & role, is inclined to hang back and not sell until the season has fairly well advanced, in the hope that prices will improve. The banks are, therefore, able to change the amount of gold required during. say, the first five or six weeks of the season, and to prepare accordingly.

Now the opening of the present soc son a month ago was marked by two features. On one hand, the price of cotton was exceptionally high, whilst, on the other, the natives, instead of adopting their tactics of former years in holding ap supplies with the object of obtain. ing a better figure, rushed to sell at the excellent rates then prevailing. As these sales were for cash, the result was that, at the beginning of October, all the merchants in Alexandria were requiring hoge sums of gold at the same time, in order to send the species into the provinces to pay for the cotton they had taught. The ordinary reserves held by the banks against the opening of the cotton season-Buch reserves being, as a role about sufficient for the demand at that period-wore equal to the strain put upon them, (although in some cases they were larger than usual) the natural consequence being a scarcity of gold until fresh supplies could be shipped from Earope. Even these, when they arrived, were found to be insufficient for the persistent and unprecedented demand which continued unabated,

In connection with the above, it must not be forgotten that a financial stringency in Egypt caused through the flow of gold into the provinces always intensified by the fact that, in many instances, the fellah does not immediately return the money into circulation through the medium of the banks. The first liability which every cultivator prepares to meat is the l»nd tax which is so arranged by the Government that the greater part of it falls due at & date coinciding with the early stages of the cotton crop sales. This tax is paid into the Caine de la Dette, and not released until the payment of the Preference and Unified coupons on tha 15th October and 1st November respectively,

It must also be taken into account that the Agricultural Bank, and other financial institutions which advance money to the fellshrine, make it a role to collect the annuities of their loana during November and December, so that the bulk of the money, is often unemployed during several weeks until maturity of these different liabilities. The balance in many instances -and especially in the case of the smaller cultivators--is then hidden in the ground, and utilized as required.

There is no doubt that a larger amount of cotton has up-to-date been cold for consumption abroad than during the same period in almost any previous year, and that prices have been exceptionally good. This, of course, means that the native should be well able to meet his liabilities with the local shopkeepers and others who have financed bim daring the summer. The latter in turn will thanos be in a position to satisfy the demands of the smaller merchants, whilst tbase again will, doubtless, take up the acceptances they have given to the large wholesale hinges here.

Although it may appear somewhat paradoxical, we think we are not too optimistic in stating that the recent demand for gold is en excellent avgory for the dae payment of bills | by the whole population during the forth
coming winter, and that home manufacturers are quite justified in lo king upon the present situation with feelings of equanimity.

If the foregoing estimate of the position be correct, as we believe will be opinion of those on the spot who are competent to judge, it follows that two references in the Economist" To the 13th and 20th October, and in other
Boglish papers, to the recount gold famine in Egypt were particularly wile of the mark. The

Economist" states that the stringency was due to the pot so much to the requirements for moving the cotton crop A8 to speculation. Now it is a notorious fact that speculation in stock and land was reduced to its lowest limit during the past few months, 80 muoh so that, in the former case, it was found onele-8 to oper the Ex.badges at all on a Saturday. It proof were needed with regard to load, we would suggest that requires be made at the Mixed Tribunals, where all transfers of real property åre registered.

It is true that daring the past few week there has been a certain revival of activity in the land and stock markets, but, with all due deference to the "Economist" and others, w would set this down to be the result, and not the causa, of the shortage of gold. In other words, 88 soon as it was seen that the orop was assured, and was selling to gengine bayers at very high prices, the shrewder members of the community realized that the scarcity of gold was & of temporary nature, and due to remarkable prosperity. They foresaw. therefore, a period of activity and big profits throughout the land, and, notwithstanding the stringency, they elected to be the first in the market in buying land and stooks which, in their opinion, were susceptible of cor siderable appreciation after the main part of the cotton crop bad been sold and the country was richer by a round of £5,000,000 ---at a moderate computation-than it was at the same period last year.
In conclusion we cannot too emphatically state the demand for gold arose in consequence of the extraordinary amount of money required for moving the cotton crop last month.

div.head: THE RODAH BRIDGE
div.p: MR. PERRY'S CRITICISM.

A few days ago we published an extract from the report of the Ministry of Public Works containing some criticisms by Mr. Perry, Under-Secretary of State for Public Works, on the efficiency of tha workmanship of the contractors engaged on the bridge over the Nile at Rodah.
This statement by Mr. Perry, although included in the appeal report of the Ministry of Public Works, was not intended for publication.
We are informed that the defects which some of the P.W.D. staff deteoted last December, most of which were denied by Sir William Arrol and Company, no longer exist. A
We will publish further technical details after we have seen the statement which Sir William Garetin will presumably make.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: At to day's meeting of the Council of Ministers, held at Ras-el-Tin Palace ander the presidency of the Khedive, the following were approved ::
A decree ordering a general congas of Egypt, on Monday, April 29, 1907.
A decree summoning the Provincial Council of the Moon Dirieh of Ghazab, for Saturday, 15th December, for the purpose of examining the irrigation works, to be carried oat during 1907.
A decree declaring the locomotive shed to be built at Tantab to be a work of public utility.
A decree authorizing the enlargement of Abou-Massoud station, on the agricultural railway between Dalingat and The El-Baroud, Delta Light Railways.
A decree authorizing the construction in the village of Etks, Assiout province, of a caracol.
A decree authorizing the formation and enlarging of cemeteries in the provinces of Kalionbieh, Menonfieh, and Dakahlieb.
A decree declaring the modification of the approaches to Rayah Tewfiki bridge to be a work of public utility.

div.head: CAIRO-ALEXANDRIA TELEPHONE,
div.p: The two new telephone circuits between Cairo and Alexandris have now been completed and handed over to the Telephone Company. We understand that every care and attention has been given to the installation of these lines, and telephone communication between the two cities should now be much more rapid and satisfactory.

div.head: TRIBUNAL CHANGES.
div.p: Hasan Bey Djelal, president of the Alex. andria Native Tribunal, has been nominated counsellor to the Court of Appeal. He is to be succeeded by Amin Bey Ali, president of the Tantah Tribunal.

div.head: STREET BEGGARS.
div.p: A correspondent complains of the great annoyance caused by the large numbers of beggars which baunt the streets of Alexandria, and suggests that the Consuls should be called upon to make an animated effort to rid the respectable pablic of those pests.

Ladies are especially postered by these beggars, who are so persistent in their reiterated demands for alms that aplees accompanied by one of the stronger sex much difficulty is experienced in getting rid of them.

The state of abject poverty, often greatly exaggerated we are told, of these mendicants renders them in many cases most repaleive, and it is by no means an uncommon sight for a disfigured limb to be thrust before the eyes of the passers-by with the object of workiog upon their sympathy.

Now that the tourist 8088on is close opon 08-indeed, we might almost say bas begonthe professional bezgara are increasing in numbers in Cairo and Alexandria considerably. and we, therefore, in common with por correspondent, express the hope that the British authorities will endeavour to persuade the Coosals to take action. A native street beggar is comparatively a rarity, and it is, therefore, all the greater disgrace to Earopeans that the Boam of their countries should be allowed to take advantage of the Capitalations in such a way.

div.head: TURKEY AND PERSIA.. THE PORTE CONCILIATORY.
div.p: CONSTANTINOPLE, November 9. The Persian delegates have presented counter proposals in connection with the frontier dispute. The Council of Ministers has drafted conciliatory instructions and manifests a keen desire for settlement in order to obviate intervention on the part of Great Britain and Russia. (Reuter)

CONSTANTINOPLE, November 9. The Ministry h48 given the commi-sioners for the delimitation of the frontier between Turkey and Persia conciliatory instructions in order to avoid Anglo-Rasbian intervention. (Havas)

div.head:
DANUBIAN CATTLE.
QUARANTINE REGULATIONS.
div.p: The Quarantine Board has decided that cattle and sheep from Romania and Serbia may be landed at Alexandria provided they. are shipped on special steamers from Constanza or Fiume, which must sail direct to Alex. andria. On arrival, these special steamers will perform twenty four boars' quarantine in the old barboar, after which, and provided they are found sound, the cattle will be landed and transported to the slaughter-house at Cairo in special trains, as per the regulations prescribed by the Public Health Department.

Diseased cattle will be immediately slaughtered at Alexandria in quarantine. Moreover the Administration maintains the right to slaughter all the herd or flook in which contagious disease may occur, without being obliged to indemnify the owners."

As the accommodation in the old harbour is limited, the Administration reserves to itself the right to restrict the number of cattle imported. It is therefore incumbent on dealers to inform the Administration of all shipments from Constant or Fiamo coming from Service or Romania, eight days before the day of sailing.

div.head: DISSENSION AT AL-AZHAR.
div.p: The appointment of Sheikh Mohamed Shakir as acting Chancellor to Al-Azhar University bas caused much dissatisfaction among the students, who fear that his appointment angars his succession to the chancellorship upon the retirement of Sheikh el Sharbini, which is expected very shortly.

The dissatisfied madjawireen claim that Sheikh Mohamed Shakir has not reached that venerable age which the post of Chancellor demands and that by his appointment others more qualified, ulema under whom the sheikh's teachers had sat; would be superseded.

A large clique of students, therefore, has undertaken to publish a paper, which is to be named "Al Azhar" and in which all their grievances will be aired. It is said that Sheikh Radi will ba appointed editor of the new organ. -

div.head: THE ROYAL STANDARD.
div.p: A correspondent writes: By what right or authority was the Royal Standard yesterday flying (as you say) "over all stations occupied by British troops, and at Kom-el. Nadroga signal station" (the latter of all places); also why was it flying at yesterday's military parade ? The popular belief is that the Royal Standard is only hoisted when Royalty is personally present.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL COMPANY.
div.p: The Contentieux of the Suez Canal Company has been transferred from Cairo to Ismailia. The service is under the charge of M. Aper, whose offices have been temporarily established in the old Victoria Hotel. It has been decided to build new offices for this Service at Ismailia, but they have not as yet been commenced.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES.
div.p: We beg to draw the attention of our readers to the announcement of a 5 per cent. interim dividend, free of income tax, which has just been declared by the Ezyptian Estates, Limited. The company, we hoar, has concluded some especially profitable transactions in the sale of some of its land.

div.head: PYRAMIDS ROAD PROPERTY.
div.p: Interest in building land speculation in Cairo centres just at present around the Pyramid, road which stretches west from th English quarter of Ghezireh. Hore land ma: be bought at from 108. to £6 the square metre and as all this part will be drained off an | lighted within the next few years the price reasonable for the most select quarter of the city.
The news that the Tramway Company has applied to the Public Works Department for the right to lay a double track on this portic of their live will give an additional fillip value.

div.head: MANNERS AND MORALS.
div.p: THE EUROPEANISED EGYPTIAN:
"Gael" writos :- Some offence seems to have been taken at my letter which you published on the 7th inst.

Nothing is further from my thoughts than 'o aggert that the generalised acougations contained in my letter are to be applied without exception to the Egyptian people. They were intended to exprege in somewhat extreme form the feelings which deter a large number of the English here--and, of other Earopeans-from entering into any social relations whatever with the people of the country.

Towards the close of the letter the accidental omission of an inverted comma after the words "we have our reasons and there they are," no doubt led those who misjudged my meaning to forget that the severe striotoreg of the hypothetical critic were judged by the writer of the letter to be somewhat exaggerated. May I quote my words 1-"No doubt there is some exaggeration in this indictment, but in the writer's - opinion it contains a good deal of truth. And What is the moral? Well, that morals are wanted by the yonngør generation of Egyptians as much as intellect.".

Such is my opinion till such facts are brought to my notice that will compel me to alter my views. Any such change of front will he performed by me with alacrity and goodwill. For being a resident in Egypt I naturally prefer, when possible, to have a high opinion of those around me. But I am discussing the present and the Egyptians of the present day. and I hold that far too large a section of the "educated" and "Enroreanised" Ezyptian h98. in practice--if not in theory-abandoned the morality of Islam for something that resemblea the negation of all morality.

As to the want of good manners and respect towards women evinced by many of these degenerate folk, I am afraid that there is only too much truth in the assertions of the hypothetical speaker of my letter, especially in the Case of the Egyptians who visit Europe. An excellent tale is told of a certain Egyptian student wbo after three years in Paris came up for his viva voce examination before a grave and dignified professor. The professor asked certain questions, the student answered with fluency and ease ; more questions, the student answered ; the professor failed to catch the sense of his reply, and repeated big remarks. Amid the general stupefaction the answer came back like a flsb, "Ah, mais ta no me comprends pas, mon cher."

Here was a young man who had been in France for three years in France and had not learnt that to tutoyer your examiners is not the fashion. He had obviously. spent his whole time in the society of persons who habitually used this very intimate pronoun, and to whom everyone was "mon cher" (at the least) till "canso contrary" had been shown. It is not necessary, I think, to enquire into the sex or the calling of our students' associates.

Again, with regard to the rather numerong cases of insult towards European women that have been recently reported. I regret to learn that po condemnation of them has appeared in the Moslem Press, and I should like to point out that such aota cadge as much, if not more, prejudice and bitterness among Europeans as Baropean acts of impolitene88 cause among Egyptians. Aots of rudeness and insolence towards respectable native women on the part of Baropeans are extraordinarily rare.

To turn to a pleasanter subject. I am happy to have the chance of expressing my high opinion of the average native merchant, of most of the soldiers and professional men with whom I have come in contact. There are the body classes who as & role are not rich and have not the time or the inclination to seek friends outside their own race. But they possess virtues which contrast with many foibles and vices of those whom I may call the "unemployed rich." I hold that this class, speaking generally deservoo many of the criticisms of my hypothetical Briton. It is too often given up to gambling or sengnality-or even to alcoholism, and even when free from the grosser vices too often shows & painful lack of unselfishness and publio spirit. Egyptians must remember that it is the defects of this class of idle profligates or selfish money. makers which obtrade themselves, and which are peculiarly conspicuong to the foreigner, who generalises from them. Remember that in this body life we have little time to do anything but generalise from a certain number of instances which are brought to our notice.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: We are asked to state that Lady Cromer will be 'at hin":after 4 p.m. on Saturdays.
The "at home" given by M-a. Guld at thì British Consulate yesterday, on the occasion of the King's birthday, was very largely attended.
Count Bernsdorff, the new Gərman Diplomatic Agent aod Consal-Gjqeral at Cairo, arrived at Alexandria "o-day by the Hamburg Amerika S.S. Oogana, ecc)mpanied by the Countess.

Among others who arrived by the Oceana from Genoa were Sir John Rogers, Count Jacques de Zagheb, Mr. and Mrs. A. Rostoviob Bey, Graf von Trenberg, Mn A. Suares, Mr. Roberto Rolo, Mr. R. C. Aitken, Captain Carlo Belfonta.
Lowa Honry Posha bag been granted special leave of absence of four month, which has been necessitated by the unsatisfactory condition of his health.
Dr. Daitt, who has been acting Coonal for Austria-Hungary in Cairo during the absence of the Consal, is leaving for Europe to-day by the Austrian Lloyd boat.
Mr. and Mrs. Hick, Paol have temporarily taken up their residence at the Hotel Miramar, Blakeley, until their new house at Balkoley is ready for their reception.
M. Vannucci, director-general of the Cassa di Sconto, has returned to Cairo from Europe.

We are pledged to notice that Prof. Balboni's monumental work on "The Italians in Egypt,". which we reviewad in our colamng rejeatly, has received the diploma of honour at the Milan Exhibition. This is the highest award in the I gift of the jury.

Terrorists threw. bombs at a mail train entering the station of Rogoff. They secured 1,000,000 roubles. (Router) .

About 70 Terrorists stopped and robbed the mail train at Rogow. They carried off £100,000, being the proceeds of receipts from customs. The exploit was thoroughly planned. The Terrorists were armed with Mauser rifles and hid in the woods antil the train arrived. They then pounced upon the station, cut the wires, posted sentinels, and blew the mail van
open with bombs, killing 16 soldiers who were escorting the money. They shovelled the gold
and silver and notes into their own bags and decamped with the utmost speed. (Peuter)

The Minister of the Treasury, speaking at Catania, announced that the year would elose with a surplus of £2,500,000. It was proposed to increase the annual military expenditure for 10 years by £160,000, to be used mainly for the purchase of new artillery. (Reuter)

div.head:
BIG FIRE IN HONG KONG
500-HOUSES DESTROYED.

div.p: A fire has destroyed 500 houses, including all the restaurants and gambling houses. Foreign marines helped to extinguish the flames. There were no casualties, Damage has been done to the extent of 1,000,000 dollars. The Shameen was threatened, but has escaped. (Reuter)
Speaking in the Chamber of Deputies in regard to the separation of the Churches from the State, M. Briand stated that the Government would remain neutral. (Havas)

div.head:
CONGO FREE STATE.
SPEECH BY MARQUIS OF RIPON.

div.p: The Marquis of Ripon, speaking at the Guildhall with reference to the Congo Free State question, said that it was the primary duty of Belgium to remedy the existing state 1 of things, but that if she failed to do so they would have to consider what steps it would be possible to take, in concert with the other Powers, to remedy the evils. (Eeuter)

div.head:
KAISER PUNISHES COUSIN.
THWARTS MARRIAGE WITH ACTRESS.

div.p: The Emperor has ordered his cousin Prince Joachim Albrecht to proceed to Damaraland for service, as a punishment for his intended morganatic marriage with an Austrian actress. (Router)

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT. DISPOSAL OF BUILDING SITES AT PORT SUDAN.
div.p: The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each term of years,
In fixing the revised rents the value of Build. ings erected by Lesseeg, will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent

Example: If a plot is leased for a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907 then on the expiration of that terin the Lessee will have a right (subject to observance of his covenant etc) to obtain a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calculated on the value the site would bear if it were vacant building lands.
Offers are invited of Premiums for the Purchase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than 1st January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered, Plan of the | Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours : Khartoum : *Office of Director of Agricul
ture and Lands (T) and Office of Governor
of Khartoum Province. Cairo : *Office of Sudan Agent (T). Port Sudan: Office of Inspector (Govern
ment Office) (T). Suakin: Office of Governor of Red Sea
Province. El Damer : Office of Governor of Berber
Province. Atbara : Office of Director of Railways. Alexandria : Office of Mr. Macpherson Grant. Port Said : Office of Dixon Bey, War Office
Representative. London: *Office of Col. Western, Broadway
Chambers, Westminster, and the Sudan
Court, Imperial Institute. Suez: Office of Capt. Falconer, War Office

Representative. For the convenience of intending purchasers the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy, at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a capital T.
Further information will be obtainable after the publication of the above-mentioned docu. ments on applieátion in writing to The Diree. tor of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum..
Copies of the Documents will be obtainable after Ist October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. or 1 Shilling per copy at the Offices marked with an asterisk.

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.
div.p: EXTRACTS FROM HOME PAPERS
Ware intend to tenant to
Pointed Questions for the Liberals.

Can any fair minded man affirm that the attitude of the Lords, since they resolved themselves into Committee on the Bill, has been anything but reasonable and moderate ? What have they done to irritate Dr. Rogers and Mr. Lloyd-George so very much? They have asserted, in language which will be understood by the people, that, as the great mass of the nation wish education to be religious, opportunities for religious instruction of some sort shall be given daily in all schools. Is this their offence, and, if so, is it because their action is likely to be unpopular, or because it is likely to be too popular with the bulk of the electorate, that it has so sorely provoked the wrath of militant Noncor furmity? Is it because the secularists and their allies are apprehensive that the people, if appealed to, might confirm the interpretation of their wishes given by the Lord, rather than that given by the Government under the stress of extremist dictation, that they are so very angry, and 80 imprudently display their anger ? ("Times.")

div.head: The Bengal Agitation
div.p: Mr. John Morley again told the House of Commons, that: his Majesty's Government does not intend to cancel the partition of Bengal. It would help to allay a mischievous agitation in that part of the Empire, make the task of the authorities less difficult, and perhaps prevent misguided people from persisting in an opposition which, if carried much further. may entail serious consequences on themselves, if those members of the Liberal party who have interested themselves in the matter could be induced to believe that in this case, at any rate, the Government they honour with their support is not afflicted with hopeless: imbecility. After all that has been said by the Secretary of State for India, a reversal of the measure which, on entering office, be and his colleagues saw good reason to adopt, could be described in no other terms. In spite, however, of the incredulity of his own side, we are inclined to think that Mr. Morley really means precisely what he has said, that he hue the courage of his convictions, and that so long as he is a member of the Cabinet tbe fatal mistake of abandoning & well.considered policy in deference to noisy and seditious opposition will never be committed. ("Standard.")

div.head: The Motor-Bus Nuisance.
div.p: If the motor buses now running were swept off the streets of London their loss would be deplored by ten persons for every one who wel. comed their extinction. Their speed and their cheapness have spoilt thousands of people for the old-fashioned horsed bus. They have opened up new routes and linked together far distant suburbs. London, as a whole, would miss the motor-'bas, and would clamour to have it back. There can be no question, therefore, of destroying the new vehicle, as has been done for the moment in Manchester, where only the few buses run by the City Corporation have managed to survive. But if the "undue noise" oan be decreased, as has undoubtedly been done in the case of some of the more recent machines, if a better supply of lock.nots and spring washers can prevent the parte subject to vibration from working loose and rattling, if the dripping oil nuisance and the exhort smoke nvidar ce can be reduced to a minimum by more stringent regulations, tben pablic opinion will endorse the actions of Scot. land Yard. 0:her things being equal, it j rob ably costs rather more to produce a motor 'bas which is not "induly poisy" than one which rattles freely and is of inferior make.
("Daily Telegraph.")

div.head: The Impasse in Newfoundland,
div.p:
The incident is significant illustration of the levity and carelessness with which the modus vivendi was negotiated by the Foreign Ofe. The framers of that document ought at lent to have made sure that they were in a position to great the concessions to the United States to which they can do by way of fulfilling their pledge if the NEwfoundlanders stand. We can only hope for the sympathetic indulgence of the Americas, seeing

div.head: Duty and the Moustache...
div.p: Lord Grenfall's order to the officers of the forces in Ireland, that they must observe the King's regulations and wear moustaches, han excited much amused interest amongst the Service members of the Honse, several of whom, in deference to the prevailing fashion, are clean Shaven. The revolt against moustaches is said to come from the "horsey" men --particularly in the Cavalry--who finoy they look emarter without them. General Wauchope persistently refused to wear either moustache or whiskers..

A late officer of the Household Cavalry tells a story about the days when the order to wear moustaches was first issued, in the early Porties. "My father was a subaltern in the 9th Lancers at the time, and every offi:er and man in the regiment was clean-shaven. To show his devotion to discipline the colonel ordered the regiment to assume artificial moustaches, marked out with burnt cork to a set pattern." ("Daily Chronicle.")

div.head: Benefitting Germany.
div.p: 'The Sea Lords have stooped to circulate a mystifying communiqué calculated to throw dust in the eyes of the country and to mislead the Press into treating a reduction of our seagoing squadrons as a positive increase of naval power ! Persons who believe that we strengthen our Navy by laying up our ships and reducing our crews will believe anything. It is the policy Sef Camille Pelletan transferred from France to Eagland for the benefit of Germany.--"National Review."

div.head: The Rout of the Radicals.
div.p: Our radical contemporaries evidently do not know what to make of thy returns of the Borough Council elections, which indeed, so far as they are at present known, are sufficiently startling. Some ignore the painful subject altogether, while with others the favourite explanation for & defeat, the caa888 of which are as plain as a pikestaff, is that the innocent Progressives have been the victims of a "campaign of calumny." Well, we suppose the beaten bide has got to say something, if only for the sake of appearances. An accusation of misrepresentation is perhaps a little better refuge than the celebrated aphorism, "he'd have won the fight if it hadn't been for the other dog" with which a coloured amatear is reported to have consoled himself. It would be stronger, however, but for the existence of the False Statements at Elections Act, and the fact that there seems to be no di-position on the part of the injured Progressives to set its machinery in motion. ('Globe.")

div.head: Male Jealousy,
div.p: It has been said that croquet is the only game at which a gentlewoman may cheat. Shocking in its implication as it is, this maxim has been readily accepted for the strength of its moral assurance that there is no other game at which gentlewomen may and do cheat. Now, however, a well known writer on golfing topics has gone so far as to insinuate that the golfing honour of women is not above suspicion.-"Vanity Fair."

div.head: THE KAISER CRITICISED.
div.p: HARMED BY SYCOPHANTIC
FLATTERERS.

Count Ernest Reventlow, well-known as an authoritative exponent of naval subjects, has written & remarkable book entitled "The Kaiser and the Byzantines," which has just been published in Munich. This book, which is a valuable contribution to current political literature, throws light on some of the most unfavourable features of the public life of Germany.

The Count is a man who disapproves of the personal policy of the present ooonpant of the German Imperial throne. He devotes the first chapter of his book to a detailed explanation of what he means by the term "Byzantines" Briefly, those whom he terms "Byzantines" are sycophants. Flattery can only produce its intended effect when the ruling monarch is naturally susceptible thereto. The implication is that William II. is naturally susceptible to flattery, and allows his political judgment to be badly influenced by the servile satellites collected around his throne.
The author says an estrangement has taken place between the Kaiser and the German nation, and that national interests are thereby seriously endangered.

div.head: Pæans over the Spoochos.
div.p: He considers that the Emperor has been encouraged to make too many speeches, some of which produce undesirable political results, by the chorus of sycophantic flattery poured out on every occasion on which he speaks in public. "This chorus of mendacious flatterers," proceeds the author, "sings enthusiastic approval and exaggerated praise, thereby deceiving the Emperor regarding the effect of his word. Tuese flatters endeavor to persuade him that his words are really daede, and that they exercise a beneficial influence of immeasurable importance."
Count Reventlow points out that the servile flattery which has become a systematic policy in Germany has greatly strengthened the German Emperor's belief in the divine right of king.

div.head: Kaiser's Midnight Ropontance.
div.p: We learn for the first time that William II. frequently feels deep regret for indisoreet acts which he has committed and which be recognises as having produced injurious results. The Kaisar, according to Count Reventlow, bas frequently lain awake night after night pondering with deep regret over th: effect of some of his speeches which have been prejudicial to the interests of Germany. William II., however, although he admits his own fallibility, does not concede to mortals not belonging to royal rank the right of criticising his acts and words.

div.head: Morocco as an Example.
div.p: Count Reventlow goes on to show how misleading were all the utterances of the German official Press in regard to the Morocco affair, in which Germany sustained a series of rebuff. Instead of criticising the policy pursued by the Kaiser, the servile Press represented bim as being infallible, and thereby encouraged him in pursuing a mistaken policy.

Count Reventlow, the patriot Imperialist, severely criticises diplomatic representatives of Germany in foreign countries. Baron Speck von Sternburg, the German Ambassador in Washington, is vigorously denounced as one of the most mischievous upholders of sycophantism, and the German Ambassador in London, Count von Wo!A-Metternich, also receives his share of criticism.

div.head: Norwegian Revelation.
div.p: It is, however, noteworthy that Count Reventlow is a warm admirer of King Edward VII, whose political sagacity and methods of discharging monarchical dates are extolled 48 approaching to perfection. Discussing some of the inconsistencies of the Emperor's character, the author makes an interesting revalation in regard to the recent change in the Soandinavian peninsula. He states that the Germ in Emperor did his utmost to prevent
h9 aogation of King Haakon to the Nor. wezian throno on the good that his selection. to rule over Norway would be prejudicial to German interests.

div.head: A STONE THE SIZE OF A WALNUT.
div.p: Miss Emily Dodsley, who lives at 5, Adelaide Terrace, Downing Street, Bulwell, Nottingham, England, tells the following striking story :

Her father and mother believed her to be dying, as well they might do; she was suffering, the doctor said, from inflammation of the bladder, and had been afflicted with it for nearly a year. A slight pain in the back had been the first warning symptom, but in the end the agony became so great that her shrieks by day and night kept the house awake ; she could scarcely crawl about ; to stand was torture;she could only sit on the edge of her chair; she spent the greater part of her time in bed, sleepless and suffering. Urinary troubles were no little part of what she had to endure. She was an out-patient at- Hospital, attended the dispensary, and was seen by three doctors, all to no good purpose. At last her father determined to try the effect of Doan's Bæckache Kidney Pills. Both he and his daughter describe the effect as miraculous, Miss Dodsley grew better, until she was relieved of a gravelstone the size of a walnut. It weighs of an oz It came away without causing that torture so common in passing even a small stone. Since then the cure has progressed rapidly and Miss Dodsley is to-day a bright and healthy girl.
Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T per box.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Lieutenant H. M. Appleton and Second Lieutenant G. Le R. Burnham, 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, have been placed on duty with the draft which the Reserve Squadron, Ballincollig, is preparing to join the regiment at Cairo. The draft will sail from Sou himpton in the S.S. Braemar Castle on the 1st December.

Captain H. C. Ellis, Royal Berkshire Regiment, who for the past six years has been employed with the Army Pay Department, has been transferred permanently to the latter, and granted the substantive rank of captain, which he held provisionally. Captain Ellis got mis first commission in the Royal Berkshire Regiment in October, 1894. He was originally gazetted to the Oxfordshire Light Infantry, but did not join it.

The combined manoeuvres of the Channel, Atlantic, and Mediterranean Fleets will take place in February next off the Spanish coasts. The bage force of battleships and their attendant cruisers will be under the command of Admiral Sir Charles A. K. Wilson, V.C. It will be the Admiral's last important command, as he will vacate the command in the following month, ander the age rules. As already announced, he will be succeeded by Lord Charles Bere furd.

Vice Admiral Sir Charles C. Drury, K.C.S.I., who has been selected to succeed Lord Charles Beresford in the command of the MediterTanon Fleet, is a Canadian by birth. He was born at Roth, say, New Brunswick, in August, 1846, and at the age of thirteen obtained his cadetship in the Royal Navy. He was promoted lieutenant in 1863, commander in 1878, captain in 1885. rear admiral in 1839, and vice admiral in 1903. Amongst other appointments, he was flag captain of the Bellerophon on the North America Station, 1888-92; flag captain of the Royal Sovereign, Channel Fleet 1994-95, and of the Hoo i Mediterranean Fleet, 1896 99; senior officer at Gibraltar, 1898-99, and on promotion to flig rank was appointed Commander in Chief of the East Indies Squadron, an appointment he held 1902-03, vacation it in the latter year to as games the duties of second Naval Lord of the Admiralty. He rendered exceptionally good service daring th3 crisis in Crete, 1896, for which he received in the thanks of the Foreign Office.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT |
Liverpool, November 1.

There is very little improvement in the demand for spot Egyptian this week. Cotton is pressed for sale, and quotations generally are 1/160 @ 1/8 lower, except Pine Brown which is onchanged. In Futures a fairly good business has been done, and the following alb the latest quotations :
Nov. 9.17d Felr. 9.2 May 92 Dec. 9.9 Mar. 9.2 Jone 9.2 Jan. 9.2 April 9.2 .

American Futures : The market this week has been very active, but prices have declined heavily, and to day's closing values are about 33 prints below those of last Thursday. The decline is chiefly due to heavy realizations, to a fresh wave of very "bear" sentiment aided by widespread manipulation, and to heavy crop movements, accompanied by come estimates of yield as big as 12% to fully 13 millions.

There must have been an overloaded specula. tive 'ball" interest, which could be forced on; otherwise nothing in the position grams to justify goch a severa and rapid decline. As far as we can judge there is no reason for such large crop estimates, and frost more or less severe has occ:rred on several occasions during the latter half of October, and even during the present week. Donboss the advance had been too rapid, an apocalaton had run wild, but we believe that healthier conditions prevail now, and that during the next few weeks then.chances are in favour of a recovery in vala98 more or less important. div.head: GOUVERNEMENT DU SOUDAN.
div.p: Concessions de Terrains a Batir
a Port-Soudan
Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochainement disposer par voie d'adjudication d'environ 400 parcelles de terrains à bâtir à Port Soudan.

Lesdites parcelles seront données à bail emphytéotique, pour une durée de 80 années à partir du 1er Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer annuel, à charge pour le locataire de bâtir. Le loyer ne sera payable qu'à partir de la date de l'acceptation de l'offre.
Les baux seront renouvelables à perpétuité moyennant un loyer variable fixé à la fin de chaque terme, soit d'accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des bâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas considérée comme un motif d'augmentation de loyer.

EXEMPLE: Si une parcelle de terrain est louée pour une durée de 80 années à partir du ler Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, à l'expiration de ce délai, le locataire aura un droit (à condition d'observer les conditions du bail) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi à perpétuité.
Le loyer modifié sera calculé sur la valeur du terrain, s'il était libre de construction.

Des offres sont demandées pour les baux emphytéotiques dont s'agit; ces offres devront mentionner la prime que le soumissionnaire est disposé à payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chacun des lots. Ladite prime devra être payée en un seul versement à la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offres doivent être faites par soumission, sur les formules dressées par le Gouvernement du Soudan, et doivent être reçues à! Khartoum avant le ler Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offerts, le plan de la ville, les conditions de l'adjudication et de la concession, la formule de soumission, spécification du bail, seront à la disposition du Public à partir du ler Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci-après indiqués, durant les heures de bureau.
Khartoum*-Bureau du Directeur de l'A. griculture et des Terrains (T) et bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.
Le Caire* Bureau de l'agent du Gouvernement du Soudan (T).
Port-Soudan*-Bureau de l'Inspecteur (Bureau du Gouvernement (T).
Souakin-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province et de la Mer Rouge.
Wadi-Halfa-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Halfa.
El-Damer-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Berber.
Atbara-Bureau du Directeur du Chemin de Fer.
Alexandrie --Bureau de Mr. Macpherson Granit.
Port-Said-Bureau de F. Dixon bey, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.
Londres-Bureau du Colonel Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster et le Soudan Court, Imperial Institute. - Suez-Bureau du Capitaine Falconer, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.

Pour la commodité des acheteurs éventuels les conditions d'adjudication et de concession ont été traduites en arabe et en français, et des copies de ces traductions, dans les deux langues, peuvent être obtenues à partir du ler Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 par copie, aux bureaux mentionnés.dans la liste ci-dessus, qui sont suivis d'une lettre majuscule T.

Des informations supplémentaires peuvent être obtenues après publications des documents ci-dessus mentionnés, moyennant demande écrite adressée au Directeur de l'Agriculture et des Terrains, à Khartoum.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Cotons.

La tenue du marché pendant la semaine qui vient de finir a été quelque peu changeante et même, à un moment donné, on & ju la considérer comme un objet de surprise à cause des revirements soudains qui se sont produits ; mais au fond, et sauf ce qui regarde la journée d'aujourd'hui, les fluctuations ont été graduel. les et sous ce rapport il n'y aurait pas lieu à plaintes ou lamentations.

Ce qui n'est pas satisfaisant, c'est la reprise de ce matin qui, en peu de temps, nous a fait regagner la presque totalité de la baisse de la semaine et qui a modifié de ford on comble la voie plutôt normale dans laquelle nous, avions commencé à entrer, sans profit peut être pour ceux qui ont cru devoir pousser les cours d'un demi tallari, tandis que les nouvelles d'Amérique auraient just fié tout juste la moitié à peine de cette hausse La spéculation a cru devoir exagérer le mouvement, et elle l'a fai; elle en-gora quitte pour faiblir de pouvean demain et l'unique résultat de ce lieu sora de rendre indécise la consommation et de l'éloigner da marché, ou tout au moins de le rendre réservée et de lui faire adopter la tactique de d'acheter que le tement pour fatiguer notre marché En tort Car, ce que nous avons à signaler pour sijond'ini est que comme minimum c'est le cours de 17 1/16 gae roos avode pratiq é, tandis que.com me c!oare c'est 17 9/16 qu'on a affiché le Novembre et le tout se résumant on uue perto de 1/32 pour la semaine.

Dans notre précédente revue, nous avons dit que la filature continentale, are plement appro. visionnée, pouvait se retirer du marché pen. dant longtemps ; cette assertion a été mal comprise et nous a valu quelques crit goes. Seulement, tous nous permettons de faire remarquer å Dog contradicteurs que se retirer pendant longtemps du marché de signifie pas pour toujours et que quand nous avons écrit cela, n'en déplaise aux banquiers qui parlent patu. réellement 8008 l'influence de leur position on des engageante qu'ils ont, il y avait un ralen. tissement réel de la part de la filatura et que si déprime lors il y a en réveil dans la demande, ce n'est que grâce à la chute au niveau de 17 1/16 pour le Novembre que ce réveil a eu lien.

La reprise de ce jour que nous avons mentionné plus bant aat dloadx poubelles d'A. marque qui nous est vie de avec 2 points de hansee, à la suite do Cedrus Baudean qu'on attendait avec 7.106.00 Belles et qui ne pors & doré comme égrenage au si octobre que Balles 6.892.000 contre 6.481,000 en 1905. Dans ces conditions, la première impression ne pouvait être que bad bière, mais la fen dont. Be cop doit New-York ce soir ferait Supposer gne le marché interprète autrement le rapport en question qu'il ne l'a fait bier, on que le parti de la baisse a réussi, malgré tout, à dominer de nouveau sur le marché. En tous cas, ai on peut le considérer comme donnant des indices quelco! ques sur l'importance de la récolte, il ne faudrait être pris comme base de calcul et, par conséquent, n'y a pas plus de cas à faire des évaluations que les hans. Biers ciblent aujourd'hui que des estimations
de 13,000,000 de Balles que d'autres ont pré. "contisées, en oubliant leurs erreurs dő 1,000,000

à 1,250,000 de l'année passée. A notre avie, tout ce que l'on pent dire est que le mouve. ment de la récolte indique suffisance de mar chandise comme quantité, quoiqu'il y ait défectuosité comme qualité à la suite des dégâts par les gelées ; mais, comme la consom. mation est estimée à 12,100,000 Balles par! Ellison même qui est une autorité indiscutée en la matière, toutes les chances sont ponr la baisse de l'Amérique.io. Toutefois, cette banese ne pourrait se produire qu'après que le coup à la baisse qui est en cours sera fini.

Pour ce qui est de nos cotons, rong admet. tons que la consommation en est exception. nelle cette année et que "L'angleterre a encore de gros achats à faire, deux circonstances qui favorisent les acheteurs de contrats; majs d'un autre cô é, n'oublions p8s que notre récolte dépassera i Ornement la quantité que l'on croit devoir atteindre comme consommation et que les plus forts haussiers mettent à 612 millions de Cantars.

On d'après le régime d'Octobre de l'Alexandria General Produce Association, nous prenions bien avoir €3/4 et peut-être même davantage d'après certains particuliers, et par conséquent il y aurait au surplus à placer. Ce point mérite considération,car si nous extrayons Ta vente de surplus en question par les exagéra. tion des prix, il finira par peser sur notre marché ef par gåter les choses. La situation de l'Egyptien est favorable, mais à condition que l'on sache écouler, le restant de la récolte en Europe. Quelques intéressés prétendent qu'elle est aux trois quarts verdad; cela est possible, mais jusqu'à preuve du contraire on peut douter de l'exactitude de renseignement: l'Angleterre, comme on dit, a encore à couvrir de grands besoins, tandis que l'Amérique, qui, pour raison de qualitée, devra consommer plus d'Egyptiens cette année, commence à peine à bouger. La prochaine récolte chez nous a été en faveur et le Novembre 1907 n'est plus en déport eur le mois courant que de 7/8 de tallari. Ce rapprochement était prévu. Ce qui est seulement peu agréable à relever c'est l'élar. gia ement da report entre les divers mois de la récolte actuelle. Pour les uns cela signifie faiblesse des acheteurs qui ne cherchent qu'à gorger de temps, tandis que la spéculation joue sa façon d'agir en disant que plus l'é. échéance est éloignée, plus aisés deviennent les tentatives de soutien et plus nombreuses les chances de succès. Le marché de disponible a encore été assez actif, mais sous le rapport des prix il y a de la baisse malgré la reprise de ce matin. Cela se conçoit pourtant, va la position des contrato.

Cette baisse, d'après la cote officielle, 88 de 3/8 en moyenne tant pour les Mit Suffit que pour les provenances Haute-Egypts. Les Abats si, par contre, maintiennent leurs cours de la semaine. passée, tandis que les Jovanovich gagnent 3/8 de tallari.

Ce dernier genre, de reste, est rare et 'De fait qu'avancer et un coup d'oeil au tableau de la dernière enchère des Domaines de l'Etat que nous publione ci dessous, fournit, par les prix payés, une preuve des besoins qui existent pour cette spécialité. On dit même qu'il y a de grosses ventes à découvert, ce qui nous paraît impossible, car depuis longtemps déjà on savait que les ensemencements de cette année en Jovanovich avaient été énormément réduits.

Les exportations de la semaine déclarées par la Douane n'ont été que de 27,500 Balles, contre 29,500 l'année dernière ; mais on prétend qu'il y a de 12 à 14,000 Balles en 808 pensé comme règlement de droits et dont une partie au moins viendra grossir les chiffres de la semaine prochaine. Avec tous ces retards on ne saurait plus faire de pronostics sans risquer de se tromper sept fois sur dix.

Liverpool n'a pas été très propice aux Egyp: tiens disponibles, di comme veneta, di comme prix : les premières ont été petites et vont en diminuant, tandis que la baisse est à signaler tant sur les spot, en recul de 1/8 à la cote de 91/2, qae sur le Novembre qui perd: 4/64 à 911/64,

Les Américains ont été plus actifs, mais Id aussi il y a de la baisse, soit 5 points sur le disponible coté aujourd'hui à 5.75 et 12 points perdus à la dernière høre gor les facteurs qui clôturent à 5.33 par le Janvier Février et 5.43 pour le Mai-Jain.

div.p: Les arrivages sont de plus en plus impor. tants, mais la demande pour le disponible absorbe, tout. Le fait est qu'il y a forte recherche pour les embarquements et que les prix, qui avaient commencé à fléchir, ont vite repris depuis 3 jours. La cote de ce matin est de P.T. 68.

Résumé des réponses reçues en Octobre 1906: 1 Le mois d'Octobre, sauf an ou deux jours de pluie, dous & procuré une bien douce température, dont les Cotonniørs ont largement profité. . La maturation des noix s'est faite dans de bonnes conditions, de sorte que dans les provinces centrales et méridionales du Delta, les deux premières cueillettes sont presque entièrement terminées ; leur rendement est supérieur à celui de 1905, et l'on compte aussi sur des résultats satisfaisants dans les provin. ces septentrionales; mais, pour celles-ci, la récolte exigera encore plusieurs jours.

Pour ce qui est de la troisième oreillette,' elle est, comme presque chaque année, très irrégulière : insignifiante dans beaucoup de localités, elle donnera dans les autres un produit plus ou moins appréciable.
Depuis notre dernier rapport, les rendements à l'égrenage se sont améliorés de 1 à 11/2 %.

Dans la Haute-Egypte et le Fayoum, op est très satisfait de la récolte qui produira, par feddan, beaucoup plus que l'année dernière, ce qui comblera et au-delà le déficit q08 faisait craindre la diminution de l'agréage cultivé en coton cette année.
Comme on le voit, ces informations sont satisfaisantes et font espérer de bons résultats, qu'actuellement nous évaluons de Cantars 6,500,000 à 6 750 000.
Le 31 Octobre 1906.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIÈRE
div.p: Alexandrie, le 9 Novembre. Ainsi que nous l'avions prévu, il n'y a pas eu de liquidation proprement dite, la plupart des positions d'octobre ayant été reportées à fin novembre.; mais deux ou trois petits conr. tiers qui avaient escompté, une baise et s'étaient trop Avancé en ventes à découvert se sont trouvés pris. Là-dessus, le coton améri. cain s'est mis à faiblir, obliguant quelque8DDS de nos spéculateurs à liquider leurs positions en valeurs pour solder leurs différences en cotons.Ces diverses circonstances ont naturelle. mont impressionné notre marché et au lieu de la reprise à laquelle on s'attendait générale. ment, c'est la faiblesse qui a prédominé durant toute la semaine. Aujourd'hui seulement, le relèvement des cotons et les demandes du Caire ont ramené un peu de fermeté dans notre corbeille et occasionné une reprise partielle.

Si toutefois de nouvelles fluctuations cotonnières viennent encore influencer notre marché des valeurs, le mouvement de hausse risque bien d'être compromis, car, avant d'avoir eu le temps de se ressaisir, la spéculation devra songer à la prochaine liquidation qui pourrait bien ne pas se passer aussi aisément que celle d'octobre. On sait, en effet, que celle-ci n'a été aussi facile que parce que les faiseurs pour fin ont payé tous les reports qu'on leur demandait, si excessifs qu'ils passent leur parai. tre ; mais, avant de s'exécuter pour des reports ultérieure, ils y regarderont probablement à deux fois, car cela pourrait les mover fort loin. En attendant, l'argent a plutôt renchéri et les journaux d'Europe s'accordent à dire que de domination de taux d'intérêt ne sera guère possible ayant plusieurs mois. Le taux privé d'escompte vient d'être porté en Angleterre de 5 7/8 à 6%
Nous avons déjà dit qu'ici les banques font payer depuis que le temps de 7.12 9 pour cent, et il n'est pas vraisemblable qu'elles réduisent ce taux avant les mois de janvier ou février.

L'attention de marché s'est particulièrement portée cette semaine sur les petites valeurs, les Delta Land, Estates, Salt and Soda, Sucreries, et Trast. Voe certaine animation, & également régné en Union Foncière, Urbaine, Comptoir, investment at Cassa di Sconto. Mais, d'une façon générale, les transactions ont été clairsemées et ce n'est qu'aujourd'hui qu'elles ont pris que certaine envergure bar les achats du Caire,

Voici maintenant un bref aperçu des fluctuations: sur une cinquantaine de valeurs inscrites à !8.cote officielle de la Bourse d'Alexandrie, 17 environ sont en hausse, 22 en baisse et le reste demeure stationnaire.

Parmi les Sociétés qui vont être lancées en Egypte au cours de cette saison, se trouve une banque de report au capital de € 260,000 en action de £ 1 chaque. Le succès obtenu par le Comptoir Financier et Commercial d'Egypte a été tel et a répondu à de si grands besoins qu'il n'est pas étonnant de voir d'autres Sociétés embrasser le même champ d'opérations. La nouvelle banque sera lancée comme Compagnie égyptienne sous les auspices de capitalistes anglais. Le capital est. déjà intégralement souscrit.

Une nouvelle société industrielle cotonnière égyptienne vient d'être enregistrée à Londres sous le nom de "Egyptian Ginning & Cotton, Ltd." Son capital est de £2.0000 en actions de £ 1 chaque. Elle & pour but d'absorber la "Prior Pibres Consolidated, Ltd." et de s'oo: couper de toutes opérations industrielles concernant le coton.
Oa donne l'extrait suivant d'un rapport que le nouveau conseil d'administration de la Société des Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte aurait envoyé sur la situation de la Société

"Le nouveau conseil d'administration a fait jusqu'ici des économies représentant annuellement 400 000 liv. st. Il y a lieu d'ajouter que le gouvernement a établi un droit de douane protecteur sur le score de 7 frs. 50. Ce droit empêche les importations de sucre étranger. Les frais de promotion s'établissent maintenant à 20 fr. et doivent être abaissés à 18 fr. Le prix du sucre est, en Egypte, de 29 fe. 50 par Bao de 100 kilos. Avec une production de 550.000 à 600.000 sacs par an on peut tabler sur un bénéfice net probable de 5 millions de francs. Cette somme est suffisante pour assurer le service des obligations by précaires, des obligations ordinaires et des actions privilégiée: 5%. Ce service exige an total un montant de 4.500.000 fr. par an. Il resterait donc pour les actions de capital en excédent de bénéfices. Les créanciers porteurs de traites de la Société ont reçu, comme on le sait en vertu de l'arrangement de l'année précédente, 40 % en en espèces at 60% de leurs créances en actions privilégiées.

div.head: JOINT SYSTÈME BÜHNE pour manchons de tuyaux d'eau et de gaz.
div.p: Manchon d'un tuyau de 890 mm de diamètre rendu étanche par la laine de plomb Bühne et soumis à une pression de 20 Atmosphères.
Jusqu'à présent on assemblait les manchons de tuyaux en y introduisant tout d'abord une tresse de chanvre et en coulant du plomb dans la partie restée vide, puis on mata le plomb coulé.

Notre nouveau système de raccord étanche se comporte tout autrement. Nous employons au lieu de plomb fondu la laine du plomb brevetée en tres es de 1 m. de longueur et posant }, ou 1 kilog. suivant les manchons, et, procédons comme suit :

Après avoir tout d'abord introduit et comprimé la tresse de chanvre, on prend une tresse de laine de plomb ou une partie seulement de la tresse, selon la force du joint, on l'enroule autour du tuyau et on la nato fortement dans le manchon ; on répète l'opération jusqu'à ce que le manchon soit complètement plein et bien maté. Par le fait que lo matage commence déjà au fond du manchon c. a, d. directement sur la tresse de chanvre, la laine de plomb se transforme en une masse homogène, au moyen de laquelle on réalise non seulement une étanchéité parfaite, mais encore résistance beaucoup plus considérable qu'auparavant.

Des essais de notre nouveau système de raccordement étanche ont été faits non seulement dans nos usines, mais aussi en beaucoup de villes qui en font l'étude à différents points de vue. Ainsi nous avons réalisé dos jointe do tuyaux de 300 et 450 mm de diamètre d'après notre procédé et soumis ces joints pendant des semaines à une pression constante de 20 atmosphères saas quo le raccord cédât. On réunit également bout à bout 4 tuyaux de 100 mm de diamètre d'après notre procédé ; on plaça les deux extrémités sur deux supports de telle sorte que la partie intermédiaire ne fût pas soutenue. On no constata ainsi aucune flexion. Par contre un essai analogue avec des joints en plomb fondu accusa une flexion considérable.
Il est ainsi démontré qu'avec notre procédé on obtient un joint bien étanche et une résistance mécanique bien plus grande qu'autrefois. *
Notre nouveau procédé de raccordement étanche offre en outre l'immense avantage de permettre de travailler par tous les temps et sans nécessiter la mise à seo des manchons.
Outre cos énormes avantages techniques, notre procédé présente vis-à-vis des anciens procédés encore d'autres.

L'appareil encombrant pour le coulage du plomb est supprimé, et avec lui tout le combustible tel que bois et coke ; la perte de plomb à la coulée est évitée, on supprime de même le sable, la main d'a uvre de moulage des têtes | de manchons et la main d'oeuvre de coulage.
Dans notre procédé il ne faut plus que des matours.
Il s'ensuit que notre méthode rend le travail plus économique que l'ancien procédé, sans parler des avantages concernant l'hygiène.
AUG. BÜHNE & Co.,
Agent Général pour l'Egypte Fribourg, Brisgau

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
